data.title: Raiffeisen Bank: AO Raiffeisenbank Russia Booked EUR840M Legal Provision
Chinese Venture Capital Firm Signs 1.1 Billion-Euro Deal to Buy Majority Stake in Audio Equipment Maker Marshall
data.description:
Chinese venture capital and private equity firm HongShan Capital Group or HSC agreed to acquire a majority stake in Marshall Group in a 1.1 billion euro deal, Marshall said in a Jan. 24 press release on its webpage.

Under the deal, the Marshall family will retain over 20% of the Sweden-based audio equipment manufacturing company, the release said.

HSC will buy the 9.6% stake in Marshall from Swedish telecommunication company Telia for 101 million euros, according to a same-dated press release on Telia's webpage.

data.title: Hold IndusInd Bank; target of Rs 1031: KR Choksey
data.description:
KR Choksey's research report on IndusInd Bank

In Q3FY25, Net Interest Income (NII) decreased by 1.3% YoY (-2.2% QoQ) to INR 52,281 Mn. The NII was lower by 3.6%. Pre-Provision Operating Profits (PPOP) declined by 10.9% YoY (flat QoQ) in Q3FY25 to INR 36,007 Mn. The PPOP was a 2.6% miss compared to our estimates. The net profit for Q3FY25 stood at INR 14,023 Mn, a decline of 39.1% YoY (+5.3% QoQ). Near-term growth remains constrained by macroeconomic stress, elevated credit costs, and cautious lending in unsecured and microfinance segments, impacting margins and asset quality.

Outlook

We revise our Adjusted Book Value (ABV) downward by 4.3% for FY26E and 6.0% for FY27E, factoring in multiple stress points and a slower-than-anticipated recovery in the near to medium term. Rolling forward our valuation to FY27E, we assign a P/B multiple of 0.95x to the FY27E ABVPS of INR 1,084.8, leading to a revised target price of INR 1,031 (earlier INR 1,305). Given the current risk-reward dynamics, we maintain our “HOLD” rating on IndusInd Bank.

For all recommendations report, click here

(06:38 GMT) OMV's Net Profit Rises Despite Weak Refining Margins

By Adam Whittaker

OMV's fourth-quarter net profit jumped despite weak refining margins dragging on its financial results.

The Austrian oil-and-gas company said Tuesday that its quarterly net profit was 301 million euros ($311.4 million) compared with 236 million euros for the same quarter a year prior.

However, net profit on a current-cost-of-supplies basis--a figure similar to the net income that U.S. oil companies report--fell to 555 million euros compared with 665 million euros the year before, but above analysts' expectations of 487 million euros.

Its operating result adjusted for current cost of supplies fell to 1.38 billion euros, which was in line with consensus expectations as lower refining margins dragged on its financial results. The company said its refining margin fell to $5.9 a barrel in the quarter compared with $9.9 a barrel a year ago.

OMV said it expects a slight rise in refining margins in 2025 to around $6 a barrel and it expects 2025 hydrocarbon production at around 300,000 barrels of oil-equivalent a day.

For the fourth quarter, OMV confirmed its total hydrocarbon production was 337,000 barrels of oil-equivalent a day.

Write to Adam Whittaker at adam.whittaker@wsj.com

data.title: BNP Paribas beats Q4 forecast but trims 2025 profit target
data.description:
Key points:
  • BNP reports 15.7% rise in Q4 net profit
  • Investment banking revenue climbs 20%, driven by FICC trading
  • Cuts 2025 profitability target, flags further cost savings

France's BNP Paribas reported a forecast-beating jump in net income in the fourth quarter as its investment bankers rode a surge in trading activity, but the lender lowered a key profit target for 2025 and said it would cut costs further.

The euro zone's biggest bank by assets said group net income rose by 15.7% to 2.32 billion euros ($2.39 billion) for the three months ending in December, beating the 2.24 billion-euro average of 13 analyst estimates compiled by the company.

Revenue over the period increased by 10.8% to 12.1 billion euros, also above the 11.6 billion-euro analyst average estimate.

BNP has disappointed investors in recent quarters and its shares were among the worst performing of major lenders last year, losing nearly 7% while European rivals' stock (.SX7P) soared, so Tuesday's fourth-quarter and full-year results will be a relief for long-time CEO Jean-Laurent Bonnafe.

Investment banking revenue climbed 20% in the fourth quarter, driven by revenue from trading in fixed income, currencies and commodities (FICC) soaring 34% and equity prime services' sales by 30%.

BNP's performance in FICC trading beat the average growth among Wall Street banks, which Jefferies calculated at 26%.

Bonnafe has bet on BNP's investment bank to fill gaps left by retreating European rivals and compete with dominant U.S. peers.

In recent quarters, the investment bank has helped offset sluggish retail performance at BNP, as record inflows into government-regulated high-interest savings squeezed French banks' margins, while lenders elsewhere in the euro zone benefited from higher rates.

BNP's market share in investment banking in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa rose to 4.9% in 2024 from 4.6% in 2023 in terms of revenue, according to data firm Dealogic.

CAUTIOUS OUTLOOK

Yet BNP also struck a cautious note on the outlook.

The bank revised a key profitability target down for 2025, without giving a clear reason, and announced 600 million euros more in cost savings in 2026, on top of 600 million euros this year.

These additional costs cuts would bring total cumulated savings since 2022 to 3.3 billion euros.

BNP is now targeting a return on tangible equity (ROTE) of 11.5% for this year, down from a previous target of 11.5%-12%.

The group expects to reach 12% ROTE in 2026, but said the number should rise, helped by its 5.1 billion-euro acquisition of AXA's asset management arm, set to close mid-year.

BNP now expects an average annual growth of its net income of more than 7% over the 2024-2026 period, against a previous forecast of about 8% in 2022-2025. Some analysts had said that BNP could struggle to reach the 8% target.

While having significantly improved its cost-to-income ratio, which measures a bank's efficiency by comparing operating expenses to revenues, BNP remains above the average in Europe.

The bank's cost-to-income ratio stood at 65% at the end of December, down from 71.4% a year earlier. That's above the European average of 53% as of June 2024 in Europe as recorded by the European Banking Authority in a report last year.

BNP has also been hit by political uncertainty in debt-laden France since President Emmanuel Macron called snap elections in June, resulting in a hung parliament.

The bank said it would propose a dividend of 4.79 euros per share, up 4.1% from 2023. It also said it planned to buy back 1.08 billion euros worth of shares.

($1 = 0.9712 euros)

Divi's Laboratories Posts Gains in Fiscal Q3 Consolidated Profit
data.description:
Divi's Laboratories recorded a rise in its consolidated attributable profit to 5.89 billion Indian rupees in the fiscal third quarter from 3.58 billion rupees a year ago, according to a Monday filing with the Indian stock exchanges by the pharmaceutical manufacturer.

Earnings per share during the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, climbed to 22.20 rupees from 13.50 rupees a year earlier.

Revenue from operations in fiscal Q3 increased to 23.2 billion rupees from 18.6 billion rupees a year ago, according to the filing.

data.title: NIO Repurchases $378 Million Worth of Bonds
data.description:
Shanghai-based electric vehicle maker NIO (, HKEX:9866) completed a repurchase of a $378.3 million offer for its 0.50% convertible senior bonds due 2027, according to a Friday filing with the Hong Kong bourse.

Following the repurchase of the said bonds, $213,000 worth of bonds remains outstanding.

China's Tariff Retaliation Could Be Start of Long Process — Market Talk
data.description: China's retaliation to Trump's tariffs doesn't seem aggressive, says Zhiwei Zhang, president and chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management. Beijing's measures only target some U.S. products, whereas the U.S. tariffs apply to all Chinese exports to the country, says Zhang. "This is likely only the beginning of a long process for the two countries to negotiate," the economist says. The negotiations between the U.S. and its neighbors suggest that there is some hope of de-escalation at some point, though the road ahead is likely to be bumpy, Zhang says. Washington postponed tariffs on Canada and Mexico after reaching border-related deals. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

Dassault Systemes Forecasts Stronger Sales Growth This Year
data.description:
By Mauro Orru

Dassault Systemes said it expects stronger revenue growth this year.

The French software maker is forecasting non-IFRS total revenue between 6.55 billion euros and 6.65 billion euros ($6.78 billion - $6.88 billion) in 2025, up 6% to 8% at constant currencies compared with 5% growth it reported for 2024. Meanwhile, the company said it expects a non-IFRS operating margin between 32.6% and 32.9%, up from 31.9% last year.

Dassault Systemes, like other European software companies, presents its figures as two sets of numbers. One set is based on the International Financial Reporting Standards--an international accounting method that seeks to provide a global reporting standard--though analysts and investors tend to follow non-IFRS numbers. Non-IFRS figures exclude share-based compensation, restructuring expenses and acquisition-related charges.

Reporting on a non-IFRS basis, the company said total revenue in the fourth quarter grew 7% to 1.75 billion euros. Operating profit increased to 636.8 million euros from 589.8 million euros, generating a 36.3% operating margin.

Analysts had forecast overall revenue of 1.76 billion euros and an operating profit of 637.3 million euros, according to non-IFRS consensus estimates by Visible Alpha.

For the current quarter, Dassault Systemes is forecasting non-IFRS total revenue between nearly 1.54 billion euros and 1.60 billion euros, with a non-IFRS operating margin between 31% and 31.1%.

Write to Mauro Orru at mauro.orru@wsj.com

data.title: Correction: Sumitomo Bakelite's Nine-Month Profit Plunges 29%
data.description:
(Corrects the name of the company in the lede and headline)

Sumitomo Bakelite recorded a 29% decline in attributable profit for the nine months ended Dec. 31, 2024, to 12.9 billion yen from 18 billion yen in the year-ago period, a Monday Tokyo bourse filing said.

Basic earnings per share stood at 138.02 yen for the three quarters, down from 192.78 yen in the corresponding period of the last fiscal year.

The chemical company's revenue rose by 7.3% to 231.1 billion yen in the nine months from 215.5 billion yen a year prior.

The company expects an attributable profit of 17.5 billion yen, a basic EPS of 187.89 yen per share, a revenue of 309 billion yen, and a total dividend of 90 yen per share for the fiscal year ending March 31.

Shares of the company were down nearly 3% in recent trade.

data.title: Nyfosa acquires the minority stake in its subsidiary Kielo and takes over organization in Finland
data.description:
Nyfosa has agreed to acquire the minority stake of 1.04 percent of the shares in Nyfosa Finland AB (“Kielo”) from Brunswick Real Estate (“Brunswick”). Furthermore, Nyfosa and Brunswick have agreed that Kielo will take over the part of Brunswick’s organization that has been responsible for Kielo's management and real estate investments in Finland during the parties’ previous partnership.

Nyfosa is taking the next step in Kielo’s development, which following the acquisition will be a wholly owned subsidiary of Nyfosa. The purchase price amounts to MEUR 12.6, corresponding to approximately MSEK 144. As part of the acquisition, the option liability that Nyfosa has towards Brunswick, with a recorded value of MSEK 38 as of September 30, 2024, will be eliminated.

Closing is scheduled to take place during the first quarter of 2025. At the same time, an organization of 14 employees will transfer to Kielo. By terminating the existing management agreement with Brunswick, which expires in 2028, Nyfosa estimates to reduce its annual expenses in Finland by MEUR 1.8, corresponding to approximately MSEK 20.

Nyfosa established its operations in Finland together with Brunswick in April 2021 with the ambition to build a SEK 7 billion property portfolio within five years, a target that has already been reached. As of September 30, 2024, the property value amounted to SEK 8.1 billion, consisting of a diversified and high-yielding property portfolio with offices, retail, and light industrial premises with an emphasis on university and regional cities in the southern part of the country.

”We look forward to further developing Kielo together with the team that has formed the company. Through the acquisition, we create greater flexibility for Nyfosa in the Finnish market”, Carl-Johan Hugner, CEO of Nyfosa, comments and continues:

”I would also like to take the opportunity to thank Brunswick, who has been a vital partner in building the company in such a short period of time, a factor that has been crucial to Kielo’s success.”

data.title: The Nikkei 225 Index Closes 0.78% Higher
data.description:
In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 Index went up by 299 points or 0.78 percent on Tuesday.

Top gainers were Nippon Kayaku (18.46%), Sumitomo Dainippon (9.30%) and Kyocera (7.67%).

Biggest losses came from Mitsubishi Motors (-14.76%), Yamaha Motor (-3.33%) and Aozora Bank (-3.02%).
